titleStmt.title: T.H. Lacy's Acting Edition of Victorian Plays (1848-1873) : a bibliography
titleStmt.author: Revised and extended by Lou Burnard

sourceDesc.p: This document is an enhanced and extended version of the catalogue of Lacy's Acting Edition originally created by the Victorian Plays Project (VPP), made by screen-scraping and re-encoding data archived at the VPP website at NUI Galway. The catalogue has been cross-checked against various other contemporary sources. Various minor errors and inconsistencies have been corrected, and additional information added, particularly about available digitizations of the plays.

Copies of the Lacy Acting Editions are scattered across many research libraries. In some cases, they also exist in digital form, usually as scanned page images. It is relatively easy to recover details of a library's holdings from their online catalogue, for example by searching for the string "Lacy's Acting Edition" or by specifying "Thomas Hailes Lacy" as publisher. It is less easy to restrict the search to generally available digital versions as there is still no reliable joint catalogue of digitized texts in major public collections, combining the digital holdings of say the British Library, the Bodleian, and other UK libraries, in the same way as has been done for many US libraries by the Hathi Trust, or more generally by the Internet Archive, and (to a certain extent) by Google Books. (A project at the National Library of Scotland did set up such a site, under the name opentexts.world, a few years back, but its status is currently unclear and unsupported.)

The ease with which the results of such searches can be obtained in a machine-tractable form (rather then simply displayed on a web page) is also quite variable. One is usually forced to fall back on web-scraping techniques to assemble a list of readily available links to digitized copies of the Acting Editions, or tedious and repetitive cutting and pasting from one web page to another.

The intention is to provide direct links to such digitizations where possible, or to a page from which a digitization can be downloaded without former formality (e.g. from the Internet Archive, which makes texts available in various formats), or with very little (e.g. from Google Books, which requires the would be downloader to complete a Captcha test). Regrettably, although 93 volumes of the Acting Edition have been digitized by Google for the University of Michigan and catalogued by the Hathi Trust these versions are not generally available online, allegedly "due to copyright restrictions". Why such restrictions apply to works published long before 1927 is almost as mysterious as why they do not apparently apply to volumes 77, 93, or 97, all of which are freely available from Google Books, if you know where to look.

Those 93 digitized volumes are however fully available if (a) you are (or appear to be) located in the United States and if (b) you are a registered user logged into the Hathi Trust site. For that reason, and for that subset of humanity, I have included Hathi Trust handles for the individual volumes below. The rest of us can take consolation in the fact that for a digitization exercise allegedly undertaken for preservation purposes, the results are remarkably poor and in some cases unusable (pages are omitted, damaged, suffering from bleed through, etc. etc.)

bibl.author: [Anon. (Tom Taylor & Albert Smith)]
bibl.note: The identification of the authors of this play is complicated: the play text describes it as 'by the authors of "Valentine and Orson", "Whittington and his Cat", "Cinderella" etc.'. Nicoll lists Tom Taylor and A.R. Smith as the authors, but has T.P. Taylor as the author of "Cinderella" and Mark Lemon as the author of "Whittington and his Cat"; further to complicate matters, Princeton University Library holds a copy of the title wrapper of the play with the following inscription: '“A” This is the Drama marked “A” referred to in the Affidavit of Charles Reade sworn before me this --th day of December.—[unsigned].' Also inscribed on t.p.: 'Fredk Bidwell'.

bibl.author: [Anon.]
bibl.title: Up to Town and Back Again by The "Old York Highflyer"

Mr Rayner's Popular Entertainment, Comprising a Variety of Tales, Anecdotes, Recitations, Oddities, Whims, and Eccentric Pictures, from Nature; Particularly Killing Jenny -- The Riding System -- A Visiting Frenchman -- Stages of Loves from Twenty to Sixty -- Love and Ladyfoot -- The Smoking Age -- Amateur Whip -- Village Club -- Cross Readings -- Wonderful Alterations -- A Curious Law Trial to Recover a Whipping -- A Wine Party Degrees of Drunkenness -- Hope I Haven't Tired You, &c., &c. Including the Popular Songs of Guy Fawkes; We Shall Never See the Like Again, Cruel Courtship, The Gallimaufry, English, Irish, and Scotch Medley, Undeniables, The Chapter of Toping, London Oddities, to Which is Added the Monopolylogue of The Yorkshire Gamester, in Which is Introduced the Favourite Comic Song of The Loves of Humphrey Suckit and Betty Bouncer
